text: Anyone see the issue discussed here? https://can01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Flearn.microsoft.com%2Fen-us%2Fanswers%2Fquestions%2F1390624%2Fvirtual-machines-failed-to-start-after-installing%3Fpage%3D1%23answers&data=05%7C01%7Cemail_ingestion%40bighatgroup.com%7C14a7a066b79343c62f9c08dbcfef86fa%7C5a01497e1bcb4711b6e6d24f4ab00393%7C0%7C0%7C638332399888458368%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=ckXLx8DI9sca9%2F4c0ov2EW49tAH4LhC7McguAR9i8UA%3D&reserved=0 I patched one host node of a server 22 hyper-v/starwind 2 node cluster, paused said node, draining roles. Rebooted and everything looked good for about 5 minutes. The everything went kaput. One of the replicated CSVs showed as MBR in disk management, instead of GPT I worked with a Starwind support guy, had to nuke and re-create the corrupt CSV, restored the one lost VM from backup and it is running ok. I patched the other node and so far things are ok. But I have a second, almost identical cluster that has many more production VMs and I'm hesitant to patch due to fear of this issue. Any advice, other than good backups? -- Link: None

I patched the other node and so far things are ok. But I have a second, almost identical cluster that has many more production VMs and I'm hesitant to patch due to fear of this issue. metadata.subject: [patchmanagement] October patches
